Content: What does the figurative language in paragraph 15 help the reader understand about the flower?

A.Choice: It stands out in its surroundings.

Key.Rationale: Imagery is the use of vivid language to represent objects, actions, or ideas. The author uses this type of figurative language to contrast the flower's “bloodred” color against the “wan” sunlight to emphasize that the blossom is bright and bold and stands out in its surroundings.

B.Choice: It prefers to grow in the shade.

Key.Rationale: The author describes the flower being “in a shaft of the wan afternoon sunlight,” so it is not in the shade, and there is no context to support the idea that the flower prefers to grow in the shade.

C.Choice: It is a color that is difficult to describe.

Key.Rationale: The author clearly describes the flower's color as “bloodred,” so it is not difficult to describe.

D.Choice: It is growing poorly in the greenhouse.

Key.Rationale: The plant is healthy enough to produce a “bloodred” flower, so there is no context to support the idea that it is growing poorly in the greenhouse.

Content: What does the point of view of this excerpt help the reader understand?

F.Choice: The relationship between Saeng and the florist

Key.Rationale: The author uses a limited point of view in the excerpt to help the reader understand Saeng's personal feelings rather than the relationship between Saeng and the florist.

G.Choice: Saeng's feelings during her experience

Key.Rationale: Point of view is used to refer to the person telling or narrating a piece of writing. The excerpt is told in third person (by a narrator) that is limited to Saeng's character. This helps the reader understand Saeng's feelings during her experience. For example, in paragraph 7, the narrator describes that Saeng is “discouraged and feeling more than a little foolish.”

H.Choice: The opinion of the florist

Key.Rationale: The point of view of the excerpt is limited to Saeng, so the author does not use it to help the reader understand the opinion of the florist.

J.Choice: The florist's desire to help Saeng

Key.Rationale: The point of view of the excerpt is limited to Saeng, so the author does not use it to help the reader understand the florist's desire to help Saeng.

Content: What is the meaning of p͟r͟o͟f͟u͟s͟i͟o͟n as it is used in paragraph 13?

A.Choice: Height

Key.Rationale: There is no reference to the height of the plants in the greenhouse, so this is not the meaning of p͟r͟o͟f͟u͟s͟i͟o͟n.

B.Choice: Color

Key.Rationale: Although the author mentions plants “of all shades and shapes” in the greenhouse, no specific colors are mentioned. The word p͟r͟o͟f͟u͟s͟i͟o͟n is used to describe the number of plants rather than their color.

C.Choice: Abundance

Key.Rationale: The meaning of p͟r͟o͟f͟u͟s͟i͟o͟n is closest to the word “abundance.” In paragraph 13, the author explains that the greenhouse was “exploding with greenery” and that there were plants “of all shades and shapes.” The use of these phrases gives the reader the idea that the greenhouse was overflowing with an abundance of plants.

D.Choice: Purpose

Key.Rationale: The word p͟r͟o͟f͟u͟s͟i͟o͟n is used to describe the number of plants in the greenhouse rather than their purpose.

Content: Which sentence suggests that Saeng's main conflict in the excerpt will be resolved?

F.Choice: The leaves on the shrub were of the same distinct serrated heart shape, but its flower looked — wrong, somehow. (paragraph 6)

Key.Rationale: In this sentence, the author explains that the “flower looked — wrong, somehow,” so it is not the flower Saeng is looking for, and it is not the solution to Saeng's conflict.

G.Choice: A slow smile deepened the wrinkles in her face. (paragraph 8)

Key.Rationale: In paragraph 8, the author explains that “a slow smile deepened the wrinkles in” the florist's face, because she knew she could give Saeng what she was looking for. This shows that Saeng's problem of not knowing the name of a certain flower or how to find it will be resolved.

H.Choice: As she led the way there, the florist started talking again. (paragraph 10)

Key.Rationale: In this sentence, the author describes the florist leading Saeng to the greenhouse but gives no hint at what is inside or that it will resolve Saeng's conflict.

J.Choice: Only half listening, Saeng wished that there were a polite way she could excuse herself and leave. (paragraph 11)

Key.Rationale: In this sentence, the author describes Saeng's desire to leave the situation before finding the flower she is looking for, which would not help resolve her conflict.

Content: Why is the leaf Saeng carries important in the excerpt?

A.Choice: It helps Saeng find a plant that causes her to have vivid memories of her childhood.

Key.Rationale: Saeng uses the leaf to find a plant that causes her to have vivid memories of her childhood. After Saeng shows the leaf to the florist, the florist leads Saeng to the hibiscus. When Saeng sees the hibiscus blossom, she recalls when, “sometimes after a monsoon rain ... she would find a red [hibiscus] blossom floating in the bucket.”

B.Choice: It was given to Saeng by someone important to Saeng during her childhood.

Key.Rationale: Although Saeng's grandmother is mentioned in paragraph 22, there is no context to support the idea that her grandmother or anyone else gave the leaf to Saeng.

C.Choice: It leads Saeng to discover a new and beautiful plant.

Key.Rationale: Saeng's search for the hibiscus flower leads her to the roses of Sharon, but this is not why the leaf she carries is important in the excerpt.

D.Choice: It is essential in teaching Saeng about her past.

Key.Rationale: There is no context to support the idea that Saeng is learning about her past. Instead, the leaf helps her to remember her past.

Content: How does the change in settings from the nursery to the greenhouse advance the plot?

F.Choice: By forcing Saeng to develop a relationship with the elderly woman

Key.Rationale: Saeng does not develop a relationship with the elderly woman. The woman leads Saeng to the flower in the greenhouse, but that is the end of their interaction.

G.Choice: By causing Saeng to identify a problem and find a solution to it

Key.Rationale: Saeng's problem in the excerpt is that she does not know the name of the plant she is looking for and cannot find it. This problem already exists before the change in setting from the nursery to the greenhouse.

H.Choice: By teaching Saeng to compromise in difficult situations

Key.Rationale: The change in setting is not a difficult situation, so although Saeng follows the elderly woman despite having doubts, Saeng does not learn a lesson about compromising in difficult situations.

J.Choice: By allowing Saeng to make the discovery despite her doubts

Key.Rationale: The author uses the change in setting to advance the plot by allowing Saeng to discover the plant she is searching for despite her doubts. In paragraph 11, Saeng wishes to abandon her search and leave the nursery, but she goes to the greenhouse anyway. In paragraph 15, she finally sees the flower she's been looking for.

Content: What is the best summary of the excerpt?

A.Choice: Saeng enters a flower shop carrying a leaf. The florist says that the leaf comes from a rose of Sharon and leads Saeng to it. But Saeng is looking for a plant with a darker flower, which helps the florist identify the plant at last.

Key.Rationale: The resolution of Saeng seeing the plant she was looking for and the memories stirred by it are not conveyed in this summary.

B.Choice: At a flower shop, Saeng holds a mysterious, jagged leaf. She wants to know what plant it comes from, so she asks the florist to help her. They look first in the nursery and then in the greenhouse before they find that the plant is a hibiscus.

Key.Rationale: Saeng's discovery of and reaction to the hibiscus plant and the other plants in the greenhouse are not included in this summary.

C.Choice: Saeng brings a leaf to a flower shop and asks the florist to identify its plant. After showing her a similar but incorrect plant, the florist leads her to a greenhouse. There Saeng finds the plant she seeks along with others that remind her of home.

Key.Rationale: The best summary of the excerpt is presented in these sentences. Saeng's conflict and the steps taken to resolve that conflict are described. The resolution of Saeng finding the plant she was looking for and the memories that the flower evokes are included.

D.Choice: While at a flower shop, Saeng asks a florist to find a certain plant. After studying the clue of a heart-shaped leaf, the florist realizes that it may be a tropical plant, so she leads Saeng to the greenhouse. There Saeng recognizes the hibiscus plant.

Key.Rationale: The florist's first attempt to identify the plant and Saeng's reaction to finding the hibiscus are not included in this summary.

Content: What does the photograph of the anaerobic digester silos and its caption help the reader understand?

F.Choice: Microbes are used to make methane.

Key.Rationale: Microbes are not shown in the photograph or mentioned in the caption.

G.Choice: Methane is held in containers so it won't escape.

Key.Rationale: The photograph and its caption are used to help the reader understand that methane is held in the containers so it won't escape. In the photograph, there are two tall containers, and the caption is used to explain that “anaerobic digester silos trap methane gas.”

H.Choice: Farms benefit from the extra food from stores.

Key.Rationale: No food is shown in the photograph or mentioned in the caption.

J.Choice: Methane is converted into electric power.

Key.Rationale: It is explained in the caption that “silos trap methane gas,” but it is not explained in the caption nor shown in the photograph what is done with the methane gas.

Content: Which sentence from the selection best shows that the Sainsbury's company tries to make use of a by-product?

A.Choice: Offering shoppers the freshest and most appealing products possible is a good start. (paragraph 3)

Key.Rationale: The tactic used by Sainsbury's to ensure most of its produce is sold is described in this sentence, but there is no mention of a by-product or its uses.

B.Choice: Special trucks collect food waste from more than 1,200 grocery stores all over England. (paragraph 5)

Key.Rationale: Sainsbury's method of converting food waste into fuel is described in this sentence, but there is no mention of a by-product of this food waste or its uses.

C.Choice: Some of the methane trapped during the process fuels the trucks. (paragraph 5)

Key.Rationale: The author uses this sentence to show that the Sainsbury's company tries to make use of a by-product. Methane is a by-product of “organic waste” produced when it “decomposes in landfills.” It can be used to fuel trucks instead of being “released into the atmosphere” (paragraph 2).

D.Choice: So far Europe has mainly led the way in biofuel development. (paragraph 7)

Key.Rationale: This is a statement about Europe's status in biofuel development, but there is no mention of a by-product being used to create biofuel.

Content: Which idea presented in the selection does the photograph and caption next to paragraph 3 best support?

F.Choice: An initial step in Sainsbury's plan is to sell appealing food to its customers.

Key.Rationale: The photograph and caption can be used to support the idea that an initial step in Sainsbury's plan is to sell appealing food to its customers. In the photograph, there is a woman holding up an apple and smiling. The caption, “Woman Admiring Apple,” is used to show the reader that Sainsbury's is giving its customers attractive food options.

G.Choice: People like to buy produce that is sold at a reduced price.

Key.Rationale: There is produce in the picture, but there is nothing in the picture or in the caption that can be used to suggest that the produce is being sold at a reduced price.

H.Choice: Sainsbury's donates fresh produce to local organizations that help people in need.

Key.Rationale: The photograph shows a grocery store and a woman who is probably going to purchase the apple she is holding, so the photograph and caption are not being used to show any donations to local organizations.

J.Choice: Unwanted produce can be a nutritious source of food for farm animals.

Key.Rationale: The woman in the photograph is smiling, and the caption explains that she is admiring the apple; so the apple is not unwanted and will probably be used to feed a person, not farm animals.

Content: Read the dictionary entry for c͟h͟a͟i͟n.

:box:chain \'chān\ n
1. a bendable series of joined links
2. a bond, or anything that binds together
3. a series of events related by cause and effect
4. a group of businesses owned by one parent company
Which definition matches the meaning of c͟h͟a͟i͟n͟s as it is used in paragraph 1?

A.Choice: Definition 1

Key.Rationale: Physical c͟h͟a͟i͟n͟s that are joined by links are not being described in paragraph 1.

B.Choice: Definition 2

Key.Rationale: No bond is described in paragraph 1, so this is not the meaning of the word c͟h͟a͟i͟n͟s.

C.Choice: Definition 3

Key.Rationale: Although Crewe's promise influenced Sainsbury's food-waste practices, the word c͟h͟a͟i͟n͟s is not used in reference to this “cause and effect” relationship.

D.Choice: Definition 4

Key.Rationale: In paragraph 1, the author explains that “Sainsbury's is one of England's oldest grocery c͟h͟a͟i͟n͟s,” which could be understood as a group of businesses owned by one parent company because there are many grocery stores named Sainsbury's.

Content: What is the most likely reason the author wrote this selection?

F.Choice: To encourage the reader not to waste food

Key.Rationale: The author is not encouraging the reader to do anything. Instead, the author is showing the reader what problems can be solved with creativity.

G.Choice: To show the reader that many different types of biofuels are being used

Key.Rationale: The author only describes one type of biofuel (methane gas from decomposed organic materials), so this is not why the selection was written.

H.Choice: To demonstrate that creativity can help solve environmental problems

Key.Rationale: In paragraph 2, the author describes the problem: dumping organic waste into landfills creates harmful amounts of methane gas. In the rest of the selection, the author describes creative ways to limit organic waste: giving customers attractive or reduced-price food, donating food to be eaten, and using methane gas as fuel.

J.Choice: To argue the importance of preventing methane from escaping into the atmosphere

Key.Rationale: The author focuses more on describing the creative methods used by Sainsbury's to reduce food waste and use methane gas rather than arguing that it is important to prevent methane from escaping into the atmosphere.

Content: In paragraph 4, why does the author compare anaerobic digesters to stomachs?

A.Choice: To show how the silos use bacteria to change the food waste into methane

Key.Rationale: In paragraph 4, the author explains that “these giant silos act like artificial stomachs” because they contain microbes that “digest organic waste and produce methane bubbles.”

B.Choice: To describe how vehicles use the biofuel created by the silos

Key.Rationale: The author is comparing the anaerobic digesters to stomachs, not vehicles, so the comparison is not used to describe vehicles using biofuel.

C.Choice: To emphasize that the silos produce the same amount of methane as landfills

Key.Rationale: Although in paragraph 4 the author explains that “the same thing happens to organic waste in landfills,” the actual comparison of anaerobic digesters to stomachs is not used to emphasize the amount of methane, just the method of producing methane.

D.Choice: To suggest that the food waste collected in silos comes mainly from leftover meals

Key.Rationale: The comparison of anaerobic digesters to stomachs is used to describe the method of producing methane, not the source of food waste.

Content: What is the most likely reason the author included the information in paragraph 6?

F.Choice: To suggest that it is difficult to collect food waste

Key.Rationale: The author explains that every meal “results in some food waste” and that food waste is “reliable,” so the author is not suggesting that it is difficult to collect food waste.

G.Choice: To argue that food waste is a growing problem

Key.Rationale: The author mentions that every meal “results in some food waste” but does not argue in paragraph 6 that food waste is a growing problem.

H.Choice: To highlight that food waste is a renewable and useful resource

Key.Rationale: The author included the information most likely to highlight that food waste is a renewable and useful resource. The author explains that the source for anaerobic digesters is “reliable” because people will always produce food waste and “valuable” because it can be used as “raw material for making biofuel.”

J.Choice: To reveal that food waste is difficult to control

Key.Rationale: In paragraph 6, the author explains that food waste can be managed by converting it into biofuel; this does not reveal that food waste is difficult to control.

Content: The word a͟c͟c͟u͟m͟u͟l͟a͟t͟e comes from the Latin cumulus, which means “a pile.” What does a͟c͟c͟u͟m͟u͟l͟a͟t͟e͟d in paragraph 9 mean?

A.Choice: Lost

Key.Rationale: The chickadees are using their “recently a͟c͟c͟u͟m͟u͟l͟a͟t͟e͟d fat” to keep warm, which they could not do if the fat were lost.

B.Choice: Awakened

Key.Rationale: Although the chickadees burn their fat at night, their fat is not “awakened”; it is gathered.

C.Choice: Warmed

Key.Rationale: The chickadees' fat does help them keep warm, but the word a͟c͟c͟u͟m͟u͟l͟a͟t͟e͟d describes how the birds got the fat rather than what the fat helps them do.

D.Choice: Gathered

Key.Rationale: In paragraph 9, it is explained that “chickadees burn their recently a͟c͟c͟u͟m͟u͟l͟a͟t͟e͟d fat.” The fat that the birds use to keep warm at night is collected, or “gathered,” throughout the day.

Content: What is the author's primary purpose in writing the selection?

F.Choice: To provide information about the best locations for chickadees to live in order to survive

Key.Rationale: Although the author explains that chickadees live in northern North America, the author's purpose for writing the selection is to describe how chickadees survive in this frigid environment.

G.Choice: To describe the ways chickadees have adapted to be able to stay alive in cold climates

Key.Rationale: The author's primary purpose is to describe the ways chickadees have adapted to be able to stay alive in cold climates. In paragraph 2, the author explains that “chickadees have adapted to the cold in amazing ways” and then explains those ways, such as fluffing their feathers, eating throughout the day to gain fat, and conserving energy.

H.Choice: To communicate the problems chickadees encounter as a result of their small size

Key.Rationale: In paragraph 2, it is explained that chickadees “are only as big as a person's thumb,” but there is no claim that their small size causes problems, so this is not the author's purpose in writing the selection.

J.Choice: To explain how the feathers of chickadees function in different environments

Key.Rationale: In paragraphs 3 through 5, the author explains how chickadees' feathers function in cold weather. No other environments are discussed, so this is not the author's purpose in writing the selection.

Content: Which sentence best supports the idea that chickadees take action to keep their bodies warm at night?

A.Choice: This means that sometimes there is well over a 100-degree difference between a chickadee's body and the air temperature only an inch away. (paragraph 3)

Key.Rationale: In this sentence, the author explains the difference between the outside temperature and internal temperature of a chickadee, but there is no mention of what a chickadee does to maintain this high internal temperature.

B.Choice: Without any feathered insulation, heat would quickly be lost and much energy wasted in attempting to keep their toes as warm as the rest of the body. (paragraph 6)

Key.Rationale: In this sentence, the author is explaining why chickadees do not keep their toes warm, which is the opposite of taking action to stay warm.

C.Choice: Since they don't have crops in which they can store food to eat later, they must eat enough each day to survive the long, 18-hour night. (paragraph 9)

Key.Rationale: This sentence is used to support the idea that chickadees take action to keep their bodies warm at night. They do this by eating “enough each day to survive the long, 18-hour night.”

D.Choice: They do not roost together in flocks as some birds do but spend the night alone. (paragraph 10)

Key.Rationale: Roosting together in flocks is a method that some birds use to stay warm, so spending the night alone would be the opposite of taking action to stay warm.

Content: What is the best summary of the selection?

F.Choice: Chickadees may be small birds, but they are very strong and intelligent. Unlike other birds, chickadees do not migrate in the winter. Instead, they enjoy staying in cold climates such as Alaska, even though the temperature can be much colder than their bodies.

Key.Rationale: There is no mention of the methods chickadees use to stay warm in cold temperatures, which is the focus of the selection, so this is not the best summary.

G.Choice: Chickadees are tiny birds that can be found in extremely cold climates. To stay warm, they rely on fluffing their feathers, eating lots of food, and using the nights for sleeping. They have found many ways to protect their bodies from becoming too cold.

Key.Rationale: The best summary of the selection is presented in these sentences. The circumstances in which chickadees live are described and the methods they use to stay warm are detailed.

H.Choice: When the winters grow colder, chickadees spend time fluffing their feathers. The colder it becomes, the more they fluff, so that sometimes they look like furry balls. By doing this, they are able to stay warm and protect their skin from the icy temperatures an inch away.

Key.Rationale: Only one of the methods chickadees use to keep warm is described in these sentences, so this is really just a detail from the selection rather than an overall summary.

J.Choice: Many people have seen the tiny birds known as black-capped chickadees. Although these birds are only the size of a person's thumb, they have very thick feathers. They also prepare by storing food so that they can survive during long winters.

Key.Rationale: This summary does not include information about chickadees using certain methods to stay warm in freezing cold temperatures, so it is not the best summary.

Content: What does the imagery in lines 9 and 10 of the poem suggest about the speaker?

A.Choice: The speaker feels concerned about how quickly the day passes.

Key.Rationale: The description of the sun being high in the sky and the icicles dripping is used to show the improvement in weather rather than how quickly the day passes.

B.Choice: The speaker feels bothered by the dripping water.

Key.Rationale: The speaker is not bothered by the dripping water. Instead, the speaker is encouraged by the dripping water because it means the weather is becoming warmer and the icicles are melting.

C.Choice: The speaker feels relieved to see another type of bird.

Key.Rationale: The trilling of the cardinal is described to show the speaker's relief that better weather is coming, not that company has arrived.

D.Choice: The speaker feels encouraged by the change in weather conditions.

Key.Rationale: Imagery is the use of vivid language to represent objects, actions, or ideas. The imagery in lines 9 and 10 of the poem is used to suggest the speaker feels encouraged because the weather is getting warmer — the sun is high in the sky, the cardinal is singing, and the icicles are melting.

Content: The actions described in the first stanza (lines 1–4) suggest that the speaker is  —

F.Choice: surprised

Key.Rationale: The actions described in the first stanza are used to show how hard the speaker and other chickadees work during the day, not that they are surprised.

G.Choice: hardworking

Key.Rationale: The actions described in the first stanza are used to suggest that the speaker is hardworking. The speaker and other chickadees work hard to “glean and gulp and pluck and snare” all day long from “dawn to dusk” in order to survive the long, cold night.

H.Choice: carefree

Key.Rationale: The actions described in the first stanza are used to show how hard the speaker and other chickadees work to prepare for the coming night, so they are not carefree.

J.Choice: greedy

Key.Rationale: The speaker and other chickadees work hard to gather food and items for their nest in order to survive the long, cold night, so they are more hardworking than greedy.

Content: The poet's use of line length helps contribute to the poem's  —

A.Choice: change in tone

Key.Rationale: Tone is the way the author expresses his or her attitude through writing, so a change in tone would be indicated by word choice rather than line length.

B.Choice: vivid imagery

Key.Rationale: Imagery is the use of vivid language to represent objects, actions, or ideas, so the poem's vivid imagery would be presented through word choice rather than line length.

C.Choice: rhythm

Key.Rationale: Rhythm is the metrical pattern of accented and unaccented syllables in poetry. The poet's use of line length helps contribute to the poem's rhythm. The same rhythm is maintained throughout the poem because each line has about eight syllables.

D.Choice: alliteration

Key.Rationale: Alliteration is the repetition of the same letter or sound across closely connected words, so alliteration would be presented through word choice rather than line length.

Content: What does the repetition in line 6 and line 15 emphasize?

F.Choice: The speaker's willingness to join other birds

Key.Rationale: No other birds are mentioned in line 6 or line 15, so this is not what the poet is trying to emphasize.

G.Choice: The speaker's confidence in surviving a harsh winter

Key.Rationale: The repetition in line 6 and line 15 is used to emphasize the speaker's confidence in surviving a harsh winter. The speaker sings and laughs at the weather because it knows how to endure the cold and that the weather will eventually improve.

H.Choice: The speaker's cheerfulness when experiencing an unfamiliar situation

Key.Rationale: The speaker is not unfamiliar with the situation because the weather gets cold every year, so this is not what the poet is trying to emphasize.

J.Choice: The speaker's enjoyment of winter

Key.Rationale: The speaker is singing and laughing because the speaker is clever and knows the cold weather will eventually improve, not because the speaker enjoys the winter.

Content: The imagery in lines 3 and 4 of the poem creates a sense of  —

A.Choice: loneliness

Key.Rationale: The absence of other birds is not mentioned, so the imagery in lines 3 and 4 is not used to create a sense of loneliness.

B.Choice: affection

Key.Rationale: Since there is no mention of other birds, there is no sense of affection being conveyed in lines 3 and 4.

C.Choice: acceptance

Key.Rationale: The feeling being created by the imagery is more of safety in the “snug and tight” roost rather than acceptance of the cold night.

D.Choice: security

Key.Rationale: Imagery is the use of vivid language to represent objects, actions, or ideas. In lines 3 and 4, the speaker is describing a place to sleep that is “snug and tight” and will keep the speaker safe and secure during the “long and frozen night.”

Content: The rhythm and rhyme scheme used in the poem contributes to a mood of  —

F.Choice: gratefulness

Key.Rationale: The poet does not create a mood of gratefulness through the use of rhythm and rhyme scheme in the poem.

G.Choice: cheerful energy

Key.Rationale: Rhythm is the metrical pattern of accented and unaccented syllables in poetry. Each line has around eight syllables. The first line rhymes with the second line and the third line rhymes with the fourth line in each stanza. The poet uses this rhythm and rhyme scheme to help the reader sense, hear, and feel the energy and cheerfulness of the poem.

H.Choice: curiosity

Key.Rationale: A mood of curiosity is not created by the rhythm and rhyme scheme used in the poem.

J.Choice: mutual respect

Key.Rationale: A mood of mutual respect is not created by the poet's use of rhythm and rhyme scheme in the poem.

Content: What do both the selection and the poem describe?

A.Choice: Methods that chickadees use to stay warm

Key.Rationale: Methods that chickadees use to stay warm are described in both the selection and the poem. The selection explains that chickadees “fluff their feathers,” eat food to make body fat, and conserve energy. The poem describes chickadees working “from dawn to dusk” to make their roost “snug and tight” and fluffing “each downy feather” to stay warm during the winter.

B.Choice: Ways that chickadees help each other survive

Key.Rationale: Although the poet uses the pronoun “we” throughout the poem, there is no context to support the idea that chickadees are helping one another. The author uses paragraph 10 of the selection to explain that chickadees “spend the night alone.”

C.Choice: What chickadees must do without in harsh conditions

Key.Rationale: Neither the selection nor the poem describes what chickadees must do without in harsh conditions.

D.Choice: Changes that occur inside the bodies of chickadees

Key.Rationale: Although it is mentioned in the selection that chickadees “increase their body weight by about 8 to 10 percent” (paragraph 9), there is no mention of internal bodily changes in the poem.

Content: Which statement from the selection is best supported by the poem?

F.Choice: These friendly little birds are often seen at bird feeders throughout the winter. (paragraph 2)

Key.Rationale: There is no mention of bird feeders in the poem, so this is not a statement supported by the poem.

G.Choice: They are plump-looking critters, with black, white, and gray feathers, and they live year-round in the forests of North America, from Alaska through Canada and across the northern states. (paragraph 2)

Key.Rationale: Although line 5, “We fluff and preen each downy feather” has a similar idea as the first half of this statement, the second half is not supported by the poem because the poem does not mention a specific location.

H.Choice: Chickadees begin preparing for winter while the green leaves of summer are still on the trees. (paragraph 8)

Key.Rationale: In the poem, the chickadees are surviving the winter until springtime, but there is no mention of what they do during the summer.

J.Choice: Although fragile in many ways, the tiny black-capped chickadee shows how tough it really is by surviving the bitterly cold winters of northern North America. (paragraph 11)

Key.Rationale: In line 13, the poet writes that the chickadee is “quick and bold and brave and clever,” which is similar to the idea that the “chickadee shows how tough it really is” as is expressed in the selection. In the poem, like in this statement, the chickadee survives the winter.

Content: Which is an action in the poem that is not described in the selection?

A.Choice: Storing food in tree bark

Key.Rationale: Storing food in tree bark is mentioned in paragraph 8 of the selection where the author explains that chickadees store “bugs, seeds, or fat” by “tucking these morsels into crevices in tree bark.” It is not described in the poem.

B.Choice: Allowing feet to become cold

Key.Rationale: Allowing feet to become cold is not mentioned in the poem but is mentioned in paragraph 6 of theselection.

C.Choice: Drinking water from icicles

Key.Rationale: Drinking water from icicles is described in line 10 of the poem with the words “We sip the drips of icicles,” but this action is not mentioned anywhere in the selection.

D.Choice: Burning fat all night long

Key.Rationale: Burning fat all night long is not mentioned in the poem but is mentioned in paragraph 9 of the selection.

Content: The selection is different from the poem in that the poem describes how the chickadee  —

F.Choice: realizes that winter is coming

Key.Rationale: The author uses the selection to state that chickadees prepare for winter “while the green leaves of summer are still on the trees,” so they realize winter is coming. However, the poem begins during winter, so there is no chance for that realization.

G.Choice: spends time collecting food

Key.Rationale: The chickadee's time spent collecting food is described in both the selection and the poem, so this is not a difference.

H.Choice: tends to become hungrier as it gets colder

Key.Rationale: The need for chickadees to eat more food during the colder months is expressed in paragraphs 7 through 9 of the selection but is not expressed in the poem.

J.Choice: becomes aware that winter is finally ending

Key.Rationale: In the poem, the chickadee knows that winter is ending because the sun is high in the sky, the cardinal is singing, and the icicles and snow are melting (stanza 3). In the selection, however, the author does not suggest the chickadee knows winter is coming to an end.

Content: What do both the selection and the poem reveal about the chickadee?

A.Choice: It is more active in summer than in winter.

Key.Rationale: The chickadee's activity in the summer is not mentioned in the poem, so this is not something revealed by both the selection and the poem.

B.Choice: It is curious about its surroundings.

Key.Rationale: The chickadee's curiosity is not mentioned in either the poem or the selection.

C.Choice: It is adapted to its environment.

Key.Rationale: In paragraph 2 of the selection, it is explained that “chickadees have adapted to the cold in amazing ways,” and in the poem, some of these adaptations are described, such as when the chickadees “fluff and preen each downy feather” to keep warm and find a snug roost on cold nights.

D.Choice: It is capable of changing its body temperature.

Key.Rationale: In paragraph 6 of the selection, the author explains that “the chickadee can alter the temperature of its feet,” but the poet does not mention changes in body temperature in the poem.

Content: According to the selection, the original Keep Calm poster was created to  —

F.Choice: instill citizens with a greater sense of loyalty to England

Key.Rationale: The British people “needed encouragement during World War II” (paragraph 4), so the posters were created to boost morale, not instill loyalty.

G.Choice: boost people's morale during a time of war

Key.Rationale: The original Keep Calm poster was created to boost people's morale during a time of war. In paragraph 2, the author explains that the posters were displayed “at the start of the war in order to raise the morale of the British people.”

H.Choice: encourage people to help fund their country's war effort by buying products

Key.Rationale: According to paragraph 2, the British government designed the original posters with a “motivational phrase” to boost morale. The intent was not to sell products to the people.

J.Choice: raise people's spirits during difficult economic times

Key.Rationale: The poster was reproduced after the year 2000 in an effort to lift people's spirits during the “economic downturn” after the year 2000, but its original purpose at the start of World War II was to boost morale.

Content: How does the author organize the selection?

A.Choice: By explaining the origin of the Keep Calm motto and its current popularity, the author emphasizes how the motto's use has changed over time.

Key.Rationale: The author explains that the Keep Calm motto was originally used to “raise the morale of the British people” during World War II and became popular after Stuart Manley put up a poster with the motto in his bookstore. Then the author explains how people have modified the slogan from its original wording, showing how it has changed over time.

B.Choice: By comparing the way the Keep Calm motto was used during World War II with the way it is used today, the author suggests that the motto's effectiveness has diminished.

Key.Rationale: In paragraph 2, the author explains that public response to the original posters was “just mediocre” and only recently became a “worldwide motto” (paragraph 3), so the effectiveness of the motto has actually increased rather than diminished.

C.Choice: By describing in detail each reason the Keep Calm motto has become an important part of popular culture today, the author identifies why the motto's popularity has increased.

Key.Rationale: This choice does not address the author's account of the origin of the motto, which is an important part of the organization of the selection.

D.Choice: By stating the cause of the development of the original Keep Calm motto, the author shows how the motto has become an answer to many problems.

Key.Rationale: The author does explain the reason the original Keep Calm motto was developed but then organizes the selection around how the use of the motto has changed over time, not how it has become the answer to many problems.

Content: What is the main idea of paragraph 6?

F.Choice: The Keep Calm slogan has been posted many times on social media sites.

Key.Rationale: This is only one detail from paragraph 6 rather than the main idea.

G.Choice: The Keep Calm slogan and its various forms have become a popular part of current culture.

Key.Rationale: The main idea of paragraph 6 is that the Keep Calm slogan and its various forms have become popular parts of current culture. In paragraph 6, the author explains that the “wartime slogan has been rewritten in different ways” and then gives some examples and tells where the slogan is seen today, such as on social media and on products sold online.

H.Choice: There is discord between people who like the original Keep Calm slogan and those who don't.

Key.Rationale: Although people have different ways of using and interpreting the slogan, there is no actual discord described in paragraph 6, so this is not the main idea.

J.Choice: People realized that the Keep Calm phrase was a good slogan for online advertising.

Key.Rationale: Although online shopping websites are mentioned in paragraph 6, there is no discussion that the Keep Calm phrase was good for online advertising.

Content: Based on the way the Keep Calm motto continues to be received by the public, the reader can conclude that the motto has a  —

A.Choice: strong ability to encourage people with its optimistic message

Key.Rationale: The reader can conclude that the motto has a strong ability to encourage people with its optimistic message. In paragraph 4, when contemplating the reason for the motto's popularity, the author states, “The saying 'Keep Calm and Carry On' seems to be the ideal slogan to bring courage and hope to people.”

B.Choice: historical significance that people appreciate

Key.Rationale: In paragraph 7, the author advises the reader that “it is important to remember the significance of the motto's original intent,” so it is not apparent that people appreciate the historical significance or even know where the slogan comes from.

C.Choice: serious quality that people find comforting

Key.Rationale: Although the slogan may have brought comfort during wartime, this is not the reason for its continued popularity with the public. The author describes the ways people have rewritten the slogan to create “fun phrases” or add “sarcasm to the slogan,” so people are no longer drawn to the serious quality of the slogan.

D.Choice: unique ability to unite different generations

Key.Rationale: Although the slogan has experienced a revival, it is not being used in the same way now as it was in 1940, and it is more popular now than in 1940, so it is unlikely that it is uniting different generations.

Content: The author includes the information in paragraph 5 most likely to  —

F.Choice: explain the origin of the Keep Calm motto

Key.Rationale: The origin of the Keep Calm motto is explained in paragraph 2, not 5, so this is not why the author includes the information in paragraph 5.

G.Choice: describe how products with the Keep Calm motto are made

Key.Rationale: Although the author explains the motto is “cheap to reproduce and easy to customize,” it is not actually explained how the products are made.

H.Choice: express an opinion about the popularity of the Keep Calm motto

Key.Rationale: The author is offering reasons for, not opinions about, the popularity of the Keep Calm motto.

J.Choice: offer reasons why the Keep Calm motto has become so widespread

Key.Rationale: In paragraph 5, the author offers reasons for the popularity of the poster, such as the “optimistic message, the simple design and understated tone” and the fact that it is “cheap to reproduce and easy to customize.”

Content: Paragraph 6 suggests that one reason for the Keep Calm slogan's popularity is that the slogan  —

A.Choice: can be used to advertise different businesses

Key.Rationale: There is no mention of the slogan being used for advertisement, so this is not suggested in paragraph 6.

B.Choice: uses so few words to express its message

Key.Rationale: The number of words in the slogan is not mentioned in paragraph 6, so this is not something suggested in the paragraph.

C.Choice: can be easily altered in humorous ways

Key.Rationale: In paragraph 6, the author suggests that one reason for the popularity of the Keep Calm slogan is that the slogan can be easily altered in humorous ways. In paragraph 6, the author explains that some people have used the slogan to make “fun phrases” and “others have added sarcasm to the slogan.”

D.Choice: can be printed on a variety of products at low cost

Key.Rationale: The cost of actually printing the motto on different products is not specified, so this is not something suggested in paragraph 6.

Content: Which of these sentences from the selection is an opinion?

F.Choice: The Keep Calm poster that Manley discovered dates back to the start of World War II.

Key.Rationale: This statement about the origin of the Keep Calm poster is an objective fact, so it is not an opinion.

G.Choice: Two of the three posters were displayed in public at the start of the war in order to raise the morale of the British people.

Key.Rationale: This statement about where the original Keep Calm posters were displayed is an objective fact, so it is not an opinion.

H.Choice: Manley's copy has become a rarity.

Key.Rationale: This statement is not an opinion; it is a fact about the rarity of Manley's Keep Calm poster.

J.Choice: Today, interpretations of the slogan are often lighthearted, but it is important to remember the significance of the motto's original intent.

Key.Rationale: This statement is an opinion because the author is presenting a subjective viewpoint that “it is important to remember the significance of the motto's original intent.” Someone else may not think it's important to remember this.

Content: Read line 3 from the play.
:box:[The audience can be heard applauding halfheartedly.]
What do these stage directions help the reader understand?

A.Choice: Pete is upset that nobody paid attention to his performance.

Key.Rationale: Only the audience's reaction is described in the stage directions, not Pete's reaction, so the reader cannot tell how Pete is feeling.

B.Choice: Pete's performance did not go as well as he had hoped.

Key.Rationale: It is customary for audience members to applaud after the national anthem, but in this case they do so only halfheartedly, which helps the reader understand that Pete's performance did not go well.

C.Choice: Pete had a difficult time hearing others while he was singing.

Key.Rationale: Only the audience's reaction is described, not the actual performance, so the reader cannot tell exactly what went wrong during the performance.

D.Choice: Pete's friends are not supportive of his decision to sing.

Key.Rationale: Pete's friends are not necessarily in the audience, so there is no context to support the idea that they are not supportive of his decision to sing.

Content: What does line 29 reveal about Angie's thoughts regarding Pete's problem?

F.Choice: She thinks Pete is overreacting to what happened, so she teases him.

Key.Rationale: It is explained in the stage directions in line 29 that Angie has a “sly grin and sarcastic tone” when she tells Pete his performance won't make it into the media club's montage called “'A Star-Spangled Catastrophe,'” making it evident that she thinks he is overreacting and is teasing him.

G.Choice: She is disappointed in Pete because she thinks he didn't put forth enough effort.

Key.Rationale: Although Angie tells Pete, “I don't think you'll make the final cut,” it is because she thinks he didn't actually mess up too badly, so she is not disappointed in him.

H.Choice: She thinks Pete's situation is entertaining and wants to embarrass him further.

Key.Rationale: Angie is not trying to embarrass Pete. She lets him know that his mistake was “boring” and won't even be a part of the media club's video of national anthem bloopers.

J.Choice: She understands Pete's distress but does not know how to make him feel better.

Key.Rationale: Angie does not really understand Pete's distress because she knows that many people have had problems singing the national anthem and that his mistake was not the worst.

Content: Read line 4 from the play.
:box:COMMENTATOR: [From offstage.] Okay ... um ... thank you, Pete Mahoney, for that ... And now the referee will get ready for the coin toss. [Voice fades.]
The reader can conclude from this line that the commentator  —

A.Choice: thinks Pete's mistakes were funny

Key.Rationale: The commentator does not laugh or say anything comical, so the reader cannot conclude that the commentator thinks Pete's mistakes were funny.

B.Choice: was not expecting Pete to make so many mistakes

Key.Rationale: Pete forgot some of the words to the national anthem, and the commentator was caught off guard, which is evident because of the commentator's pauses and difficulty finding the words to describe the performance.

C.Choice: is concerned that Angie was not able to catch Pete's mistakes on film

Key.Rationale: The commentator does not mention Angie, so there is no context to support the idea that the commentator is concerned about this.

D.Choice: knows that people did not notice Pete's mistakes

Key.Rationale: The commentator noticed Pete's mistakes, so it is likely that the people noticed them as well.

Content: In lines 18 through 23, the stage directions most help the reader understand the  —

F.Choice: stress that the characters experience as a result of their responsibilities

Key.Rationale: Pete is experiencing stress because he thinks he embarrassed himself, but Angie does not think anything is wrong, and she is not stressed about her responsibility.

G.Choice: familiarity the characters have with each other

Key.Rationale: The stage directions are not used to indicate how familiar the characters are with each other but rather to show how they interact.

H.Choice: conflicting viewpoints of the characters

Key.Rationale: The stage directions in lines 18 through 23 can be used to help the reader understand the conflicting viewpoints of the characters. Pete “firmly” tells Angie to delete the video of him singing, and she “firmly” refuses. Pete's anger rises, but Angie is calm because she thinks there is no reason for him to be upset.

J.Choice: lack of understanding the characters have about their tasks

Key.Rationale: The stage directions are used to show the conflict between Pete and Angie, not their lack of understanding about their tasks.

Content: One way Angie tries to encourage Pete is by  —

A.Choice: promising him that he will find great fame on the Internet

Key.Rationale: In line 29 Angie jokes that Pete's rendition of the national anthem wouldn't make it into the media club's montage called “'A Star-Spangled Catastrophe,'” which they would post on the Internet. She does not think he will find fame on the Internet.

B.Choice: explaining to him that she was too busy taping the football game to see his performance

Key.Rationale: Although Angie tells Pete she will tell the media coordinator that she “missed the national anthem,” this is just a joke. She did not miss Pete's singing and actually says to Pete in line 9 that he “sounded great.”

C.Choice: telling him that he will be on a video with others who also sang the national anthem at football games

Key.Rationale: In line 29, Angie does not tell Pete that he will be on a video with others. Instead, Angie teases Pete by telling him that his performance is too boring for the media club's video montage.

D.Choice: reminding him that singing the national anthem is something most people are not brave enough to do

Key.Rationale: One way Angie tries to encourage Pete is by reminding him of his bravery. In line 23, Angie tells Pete, “If people give you a hard time, remind them that they would never stand in front of 2,500 people to belt out one of America's most difficult songs.”

Content: What is the best summary of the play?

F.Choice: A boy is humiliated when he forgets the words to the national anthem while singing at a football game, but his friend helps him understand that many people have made similar mistakes.

Key.Rationale: The best summary is presented in this sentence. Pete's conflict is described, and the resolution offered by Angie is restated.

G.Choice: A boy is surprised to learn that he was filmed while singing the national anthem, but his friend promises to erase the recording.

Key.Rationale: Pete being recorded is not the main conflict of the selection, so this is not the best summary.

H.Choice: A boy is angry when he finishes singing the national anthem at a football game, but his friend persuades him to sing a different song later so that he can feel better.

Key.Rationale: Angie does not persuade Pete to sing a different song later so that he can feel better, so this is not the best summary.

J.Choice: A boy is upset when he forgets the words to the national anthem, but his friend compliments his voice and makes him feel better.

Key.Rationale: Angie's compliments of Pete's voice do not make Pete feel better, so this is not the best summary.
